name: Zotepine
summary: Zotepine is an atypical antipsychotic used primarily for the treatment of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders.
description: Zotepine is a second-generation (atypical) antipsychotic with dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2 receptor antagonism, and additional noradrenaline reuptake inhibition. It is used in the management of schizophrenia, particularly in cases with negative symptoms, and in some mood disorders. Zotepine is not widely available in all countries, and its use is more common in parts of Europe and Asia. Sedative and weight gain effects are notable, and careful metabolic monitoring is recommended.

sections.text: Zotepine acts as an antagonist at dopamine D1 and D2 receptors and serotonin 5-HT2 receptors, with additional norepinephrine reuptake inhibition, contributing to its mood-stabilizing and antidepressant effects.

adult.oral: Initial dose 25–50 mg/day in divided doses; increase gradually to a usual range of 75–300 mg/day depending on response and tolerability.

sections.text: Therapeutic effects may begin within 1–2 weeks, with full benefit potentially requiring several weeks.

other: Increased mortality in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis
Risk of extrapyramidal symptoms and tardive dyskinesia

sections.pregnancy: Limited human data; use only if potential benefit outweighs risk
sections.lactation: Unknown if excreted in human milk; use caution
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity to adverse effects; lower initial dose recommended

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over several weeks to avoid withdrawal symptoms or rapid relapse.

items: Particularly sedating compared to some other atypical antipsychotics
Not approved in the United States
